Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Monitoring Desalination Membrane Fouling via Real-time Integrated Surface Imaging and Advanced Machine Learning
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to enable monitoring and decision support for membrane-based water treatment and desalination processes in the municipal water reuse, agriculture and industrial sectors. The proposed technology will integrate of machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) decision support technology with hardware for direct and real-time visualization of process element conditions and performance process monitoring to reduce operational risks and costs. Moreover, the proposed platform will enable more efficient and lower-cost water production from non-traditional and underutilized source waters, such as municipal and industrial wastewater, high salinity and/or contaminated groundwater, and seawater. <br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will advance translation of a real-time detection, characterization and forecasting of membrane fouling and scaling of reverse osmosis (RO) and nanofiltration (NF) membranes in water treatment and desalination plants. ML and AI approaches will integrate direct and real-time membrane surface foulant imaging with operating performance data for real-time analysis and forecasting of plant fouling and its impact on plant performance. The research will explore relationships between foulant/scalant characteristics and plant process conditions for a Dynamic Bayesian Network model to inform a decision support system for timely fouling/scaling mitigation in RO/NF plants.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Noria's NSF SBIR Phase I project results have established the proof-of-concept that real-time monitoring of the performance of membrane-based water desalination plants is technically and commercially viable and needed to improve plant operations. Membrane based reverse osmosis (RO) and nanofiltration (NF) have become the dominant desalination technologies accounting for 65% of worldwide desalination capacity. RO technology is widely used for seawater desalination, and RO/NF processes are utilized in water treatment/desalination of both industrial and agricultural source water, as well as in municipal water reuse applications. Although RO desalination technology is advancing, RO membrane fouling, and mineral scaling remain serious process impediments. Fouling/scaling block the membrane surface, significantly diminishing the RO process. Delays in taking corrective actions can lead to process interruptions, reduced productivity, increased energy utilization, decreased membrane lifetime, and thus greater process costs.

      In order to address the above deficiency, Noria developed a working prototype RO membrane monitoring system called the "RO-Spotlight" that enables direct membrane surface visualization and determination of the fouled/scaled membrane surface coverage. Computer vision algorithms were developed to analyze membrane surface images to determine the progression of fouled/scaled areas during RO/NF operations, size distribution of fouled/scaled domains, and to identify the basic types of surface foulants. In order to assess the technical viability real-time RO membrane monitoring, the RO-Spotlight was evaluated using a rich database of surface images of fouled/scaled RO/NF membranes, over a range of different desalination operating conditions. Real-time membrane surface imaging data, along with RO-Spotlight onboard sensors and desalination plant data (flow, pressure, salinity, temperature) served to provide a detailed real-time monitoring of the onset and progression of membrane fouling/scaling correlated with the RO-Spotlight membrane unit and plant performance data. Laboratory and field tests demonstrated the RO-Spotlight capability for detecting the onset and quantify the evolution of RO membrane fouling/scaling in desalination of seawater, brackish groundwater, mine drainage water, and secondary treated municipal wastewater.

Noria's solution of direct membrane surface visualization, performance monitoring, and instant cloud data reporting of membrane conditions was shown to provide unambiguous information about RO membrane fouling/scaling. The RO-Spotlight technology provides the ability to visualize the appearance of mineral scale crystals, deposition of particulate matter and biofoulants (e.g., algae) on the membrane surface. Identification of foulant type was shown to be feasible enhanced contrast illumination, near infrared hyperspectral imaging, and geometric analysis for improved foulant/scale detection. The extensive time-series data of RO membrane fouling/scaling datasets derived under actual field conditions in this project are a unique resource for advancing the science of fouling/scale kinetics and identification of various factors which impact membrane fouling/scaling. In this regard, the RO-Spotlight will change the science landscape by providing data needed to develop, test and validate models of RO/NF membrane fouling/scaling and cleaning protocols.

Quantification of the fouled and/or scaled membrane areas via the RO-Spotlight technology in real time provides the metrics necessary for decision support to trigger timely mitigation actions such as the adjustment to process conditions and membrane cleaning protocols. The economic benefits derived from the RO-Spotlight technology will accrue through minimization of plant shutdowns and service interruptions, reduced membrane cleaning costs, and costs savings from the elimination of overuse of treatment chemicals. The membrane longevity will increase as will plant efficiency, allowing safer operation at the optimal high productivity. The net result will be the lower levelized cost of desalted water. It is stressed that social benefits include reduction of RO/NF residual concentrate volumes, and increased ability to treat challenging water sources of high fouling/scaling propensity, thereby expanding the world's potable water portfolio and the capacity for water reuse. An additional benefit is the development of a disruptive desalination technology that will lead to strengthening critical water resources, infrastructure, and water security, all critical in regions experiencing water scarcity in the United States and elsewhere in the world.
